'''Onora Sylvia O'Neill, Baroness O'Neill of Bengarve''' {{postnominals|country=GBR|CH|CBE|FRS|FBA|FMedSci}} (born 23 August 1941) is a philosopher and a [[crossbench]] member of the [[House of Lords]].

The daughter of [[Con O'Neill (diplomat)|Sir Con Douglas Walter O'Neill]], she was educated partly in Germany and at [[St Paul's Girls' School]], London before studying philosophy, psychology and physiology at [[Oxford University]]. She went on to complete a doctorate at [[Harvard University]], with [[John Rawls]] as supervisor. During the 1970s she taught at [[Barnard College]], the women's college in [[Columbia University]], New York City. In 1977 she returned to Britain and took up a post at the [[University of Essex]]; she was Professor of Philosophy there when she became Principal of [[Newnham College, Cambridge|Newnham College]], [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge]] in 1992.

She is an Emeritus Professor of Philosophy at the [[University of Cambridge]], a former President of the [[British Academy]] 1988–1989 and chaired the [[Nuffield Foundation]] 1998–2010.<ref>[http://www.britac.ac.uk/misc/officers.cfm Biography of Officers] of the [[British Academy]]</ref> In 2003, she was the founding President of the British Philosophical Association (BPA). In 2013 she held the Spinoza Chair of Philosophy at the [[University of Amsterdam]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uva.nl/en/disciplines/philosophy/home/components-centrecolumn/the-spinoza-chair.html|title=The Spinoza Chair|author=Universiteit van Amsterdam|work=uva.nl}}</ref> Until October 2006, she was the Principal of [[Newnham College, Cambridge]], and she currently chairs the [[Equality and Human Rights Commission]].

==Philosophy==
O'Neill has written widely on political philosophy and ethics, international justice, bioethics and the philosophy of [[Immanuel Kant]].

Across various works, O'Neill has defended and applied a constructivist interpretation of [[Kantian ethics]] heavily influenced by, and critical of, the work of [[John Rawls]], emphasising the importance of trust, consent and respect for autonomy in a just society. She has written extensively about trust, noting "that people often choose to rely on the very people whom they claimed not to trust" and suggesting that we "need to free professionals and the public service to serve the public...to work towards more intelligent forms of accountability...[and] to rethink a media culture in which spreading suspicion has become a routine activity".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.open2.net/reith2002/onora_oneill_trust_p.html|title=Reith 2002: A Question of Trust - Onora O'Neill|work=OpenLearn}}</ref>

==Honours and distinctions==
O'Neill has been President of the [[Aristotelian Society]] (1988 to 1989), a member of the [[Animal Procedures Committee]] (1990 to 1994), chair of [[Nuffield Council on Bioethics]] (1996 to 1998), a member and then acting chair of the [[Human Genetics Advisory Commission]] (1996 to 1999) and a member of the select committee on BBC Charter Review.  She is presently chair of the [[Nuffield Foundation]] (since 1997), a trustee of [[Sense About Science]] (since 2002), a trustee of the [[Ditchley Foundation]], and a trustee of the Gates Cambridge Trust. She also served as President of the [[British Academy]] between 2005 and 2009. She is on the Advisory Board of Incentives for Global Health, the NGO formed to develop the [[Health Impact Fund]] proposal.

In 1999, she was created a [[life peer]] as '''Baroness O'Neill of Bengarve''', of The Braid in the [[County Antrim|County of Antrim]], and in 2007 was elected an [[Honorary Fellow of the Royal Society|Honorary FRS]].<ref>[http://www.britac.ac.uk/news/release.asp?NewsID=252 British Academy Press Release]</ref> She is also a Foreign Honorary Member of the [[American Academy of Arts and Sciences]] (1993) and the [[Austrian Academy of Sciences]] (2002), a Foreign Member of the [[American Philosophical Society]] (2003), and Hon. Member [[Royal Irish Academy]] (2003), a Foreign Member of the [[German Academy of Sciences Leopoldina|Leopoldina]] (2004) and the [[Norwegian Academy of Science and Letters|Norwegian Academy of Sciences]] (2006)<ref>[http://biographies.parliament.uk/parliament/default.asp?id=37723 House of Lords biography]</ref> and a Fellow of the [[Academy of Medical Sciences]].<ref>[[Debretts]] People of Today 2007</ref> She is an elected fellow of the [[Hastings Center]], an independent bioethics research institution.<ref>[http://www.thehastingscenter.org/who-we-are/our-team/hastings-center-fellows/ The Hastings Center] Hastings Center Fellows. Accessed 6 November 2010</ref> In 2004 she was awarded an Honorary Degree (Doctor of Letters) from the [[University of Bath]]. She is a Distinguished Senior Fellow of the School of Advanced Study, University of London, an honour awarded in 2009.

O'Neill also received an Honorary Doctorate from [[Heriot-Watt University]] in 2007 <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www1.hw.ac.uk/annual-review/2007/people_awards.html|title=Annual Review 2007 : Principal's Review|website=www1.hw.ac.uk|access-date=2016-03-29}}</ref>

In October 2012, she was nominated as the next Chair of the [[Equality and Human Rights Commission]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Baroness Onora O'Neill to head human rights body|url=http://www.scotsman.com/news/uk/baroness-onora-o-neill-to-head-human-rights-body-1-2561749|newspaper=The Scotsman}}</ref> and confirmed as such in January 2013.

O'Neill was appointed a [[Member of the Order of the Companions of Honour]] (CH) in the 2014 New Year Honours for services to philosophy and public policy.<ref name="germanorders"/>

In 2014 O'Neill was elected to the German order [[Pour le Mérite|Pour le mérite für Wissenschaften und Künste]].<ref name="germanorders">{{LondonGazette|issue=60728|supp=yes|startpage=5|endpage=|date=31 December 2013}}</ref>

In February 2016 she was awarded the Knight Commander’s Cross of the [[Order of Merit of the Federal Republic of Germany]] for her outstanding contribution to moral and ethical questions of trust, accountability in civic life, justice and virtue.<ref>{{cite web|title=Scholar Baroness O'Neill of Bengarve awarded Knight Commander’s Cross of the Order of Merit|url=http://www.uk.diplo.de/Vertretung/unitedkingdom/en/__pr/Embassy__Events/02/BaronessONeill.html|website=German Missions in the United Kingdom|accessdate=16 February 2016}}</ref>

Currently, she is the president of the Society for Applied Philosophy, a society founded in 1982 with the aim of promoting philosophical study and research that has a direct bearing on areas of practical concern.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Society for Applied Philosophy |url=http://www.appliedphil.org/view/index.html|website=The Society for Applied Philosophy President: Baroness Onora O'Neill}}</ref>
